She sells milk in the Saatli bazaar. Her family expenditures are going up as her children grow. Humay plans to increase the number of cattle to make her income higher. But this project requires investment. This winter she applied for $500 from the Normicro Saatli branch. She hopes this credit will help her change her family life.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Hafiza

texts.ru:
Hafiza Shodievna P. lives in the Hurson region. She is 47 years old, married and has 5 children. She has a High School education and is currently unemployed. She takes care of her big family and works in the filed. The family owns a piece of land on which they sow wheat. When the wheat is ready they sell it on the market, keeping enough to provide for the family for the entire year. This business helps take care of the family financially. In addition to that wheat, is a good that is always in demand in Tajikistan, so Hafiza's business helps provide the population with flower. She plans to repay the loan in a 12 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Пирова Хафиза Шодиевна проживает в районе Хуросон. Возраст 47 лет , замужем имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее.Нигде не работает. Домохозяйка ,занимается земледелием. Имеет участок земли .засеивает пшеницей , а затем собрвав урожай реализует на рынке , а так же оставляет запас зерна своей семье на весь год.Этот бизнес помогает поддерживать финансовую сторону семьи.Кроме того спрос на пшеницу всегда имеет спрос на рынках Таджикистана , поэтому и ее бизнес помогает обеспечить население мукой.Погасить кредит клиентка планирует за 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Azarias

texts.pt:
Azarias O. was born second of 3 brothers in 1961, in the Macia district of Gaza province. He studied until the 9th grade, and lived with his parents until 1984, after which he married and had 2 children. After separating from his first wife, he married again in 1991 and had 4 more children.

Azarias began working at a glassware company, Companhia Vidreira de Moçambique, in 1982 as an electrician, and remained there 21 years. Since 2005 he has worked at BananaLândia, a banana-producing company, also as an electrician.

The first time Azarias applied to a credit institution he requested 10,000.00 MT to build his home. With this loan of 15,000.00 MT, he intends to continue the construction of the house where he and his wife and 4 young children are living. In the future he intends to have more credit to build a protective wall around his yard for more privacy.

Translated from Portuguese by Jill Haring, Kiva volunteer.

Localização: Bairro 03 - Boane Cliente: Azarias O. Actividade: Habitação Aplicação: Compra de material de construção Montante: 15.000,00MT Inicio: 29/02/2008 Fim: 30/06/2009

Azarias O. nasceu no distrito da Macia província de Gaza em 1961. Tem 3 irmãos e ele é o segundo. Estudou ate a 9ª classe. Viveu sob a responsabilidade dos pais ate 1984 altura em que casou-se e do mesmo matrimónio gerou 2 filhos tendo depois separado se da 1ª esposa. Em 1991 Juntou se maritalmente e teve outros 4 filhos.

Começou a trabalhar na companhia vidreira de Moçambique em 1982 como electricista industrial durante 21 anos.

De 2005 ate então trabalha na BananaLândia uma empresa de producao de Banana, também como electricista.

Nunca antes havia trabalhado com uma instituições de credito, mas sim esta e a 1ª com quem ele trabalha, tendo solicitado o primeiro emprestimo no valor de 10.000,00MT para a actividade de construcao da sua moradia.

Com o emprestimo de 15.000,00MT, pretende dar continuidade com os trabalhos da obra na qual ele vive com a esposa e 4 filhos menores.

Futuramente pretende um credito para construir o muro de vedação do seu quintal para maior privacidade familiar.

loans.use: To buy construction materials to build family home

loans.name: Elly

texts.en:
Elly is a married woman with 2 children, ages 10 and 2 years old. She and her husband also take care of 1 other child, age 4 years old. Elly owns a small clothes shop, which she started in 2003. Every day, she works from 8 am to 6 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $350 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Jackeline

texts.es:
Jackeline is 20 years old with two young children. She has been selling prepared foods for more than two years. In the winter, she goes out with her cart to sell hot broth or mazamorra (a sweet dessert made of corn). In the summer, she offers ceviche ( raw seafood marinated in lemon juice and spices) and chicha morada (a sweet soft drink made of purple corn and cinnamon). Jackeline says that her clients look for her every night. With the loan she has requested, she will buy ingredients with which to prepare her food products.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Jackeline tiene 29 años y dos hijos pequeños. Ella viene trabajando más de dos años en la venta de comida. Dependiendo si es invierno, ella sale con su carreta a vender caldo o mazamorra. Pero si es verano, ofrece cebiche y chicha morada. Jackeline dice que su clientela todas las noches la buscan. Con los préstamos que ha pedido, ella ha comprado ingredientes para elaborar sus comidas.

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make the prepared foods she offers

loans.name: Maria Del Rosario

texts.es:
Rosario started her business so she could help her children get ahead and help her husband with family expenses, since they wanted to own a house. She started working about three years ago on the invitation of a friend and has dedicated herself to selling footwear. She began by selling her items to friends and neighbors until little by little she was able to add more customers.

Now Rosario is requesting a loan of $250, which she plans to repay within three months, to stock up on shoes for graduation, which is fast approaching. With your support Rosario will be able to keep moving ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva volunteer

Rosario inició el negocio para sacar adelante a sus hijos y ayudar a su esposo ya que deeaban tener su casa, y forjar un patrimonio para sus hijos. Comenzó su negocio por por invitacion de una amiga hace aproximadamente 3 años, se decida a la venta de zapatos, empezo vendiendo entre sus amigos y vecinos, hasta que poco a poco se ha ido haciendo de mas clientes.

Ahora necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para surtir calzado escolar para las graduaciones, que estan proximas. Con tu apoyo Rosario saldra adelante.

loans.use: Purchase supplies / Comprar mercancia

loans.name: Edina J

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Edina M., 36 is married, and has four children aged between 3 and 15. She has one dependent, who lives with her because she is an orphan. In 2004, Edina established her crops business. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $250 every month from this business. Edina requires a loan in order to buy more stock of maize in bulk. She thanks you for your support.  

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed uncreditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from the client, extending a loan to then, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy more stock of maize in bulk.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is 41 years old. She is married with 3 children aged 18, 15, and 10 years old. She has been a banana seller since 2004. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Anna now hopes for a loan to buy more bananas for her business.

loans.use: To buy more bananas for her business

loans.name: Mwanamimi

texts.en:
Mwanamimi is 49 years and is divorced with 2 children ages 11 and 9. She has been selling charcoal and bites since 2005. She works everyday from 8.30am to 4pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Mwanamimi is now requesting a loan to to buy more charcoal to sell and improve her sales.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Nermina

texts.en:
Nermina S. is 28 years old and comes from Bijeljina. She is married and her husband has a seasonal job. They have a 5-year-old son and a 2-year-old daughter. Nermina works in a butcher's shop and besides that she has a garden at home.

Nermina made an agreement with the owner of the butcher's shop to sell chicken meat that she produces in the butcher's shop where she works. She was already busy with raising poultry as her seasonal work and now she wants to do it again. That is the reason why she has requested a loan through WWI in the amount of 1200 KM.

Nermina will use this amount to buy chickens and chickenfeed. She hopes to earn enough to support her family when her husband doesn`t have work.

loans.use: To buy chickens and chickenfeed

loans.name: Angela

texts.es:
Ángela  vive en la calle “ 1 “  de la zona Santiago Primero en la ciudad de El Alto.
 
Es viuda vive junto a su hija y sus nietos, en su propio domicilio.

 Se dedica a la venta de comida en su puesto callejero ubicado en la parte comercial de la ciudad del Alto. Sus precios son  muy económicos y destinados a gente con escasos recursos.

El crédito lo destinara en la adquisición de en mesón metálico para su mejor atención a sus comensales.
 
 
Es el quinto  crédito con Impro, y el segundo vía KIVA; la evaluación realizada lo califica para otorgarle el crédito.
texts.en:
Ángela lives on 1 street in Santiago Primero neighborhood of El Alto city. She is a widow and lives with her daughter and grandchildren in her own home. She sells food froma stand located in the commercial part of El Alto city. Her prices are very inexpensive and aimed at people with few resources. The loan will be used to buy a metal counter to better serve her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a metal counter to better serve her customers

loans.name: Juliet Uche

texts.en:
Juliet has a restaurant business where she sells drinks, pepper soup, fried meat, and cooked foods. Juliet has been in this business for a long time. She is 35 years old and married with 3 children.

Juliet needs the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more drinks, juice, and foodstuffs to cook and sell to her customers. She is indeed grateful to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, juice, and foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Caritina

texts.es:
La señora es casada, tiene 54 años de edad, su conyugue se encuentra trabajando en Argentina como constructor, tiene un hijo mayor, vive en la ciudad de Pilar, en casa propia, en el barrio 12 Octubre de esta ciudad, en dicha residencia particular cuenta con las comodidades para el hogar, en el mismo domicilio posee un local de un taller de carpintería donde se realiza trabajos de todo tipo, ya sea compostura y trabajos por pedido. 
Esta en esta actividad como ya mas de 12 años, posee todas las maquinarias necesarias para el desarrollo de su actividad que fuera para dentro del taller.
Solicita el crédito para comprar madera para realizar trabajos que tienen pedidos para entregar.
texts.en:
Caritina is 54 years old and married. Her husband works in construction in Argentina. She has an adult son and she lives in the town of Pilar, in her own house in the neighbourhood of 12 Octubre. She has all she needs in her home, where she has a carpentry workshop to carry out all sorts of work, whether is be assembly or made-to-order. She has been in this business for more than 12 years and owns all the machinery needed for carpentry in her workshop. She is requesting the loan in order to buy materials for orders which they have to deliver.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy material for carpentry

loans.name: Scholastica Naggita ‘S Group

texts.en:
Scholastica is the leader of a four member group. She is 58 years old and married with six children. None of her children, who are between the ages of 28 and 38, go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in a three-roomed house that she owns in which five people stay. They have electricity and piped water at home and the family gets three meals a day. She works in a semi-urban area in Kampala city centre.

Scholastica sells domestic products in Kikuubo, one of busiest places in Kampala. She works six days a week and rents her business premises for 100,000 per month. She sells to an average of ten customers a day and to all categories of people. She sells retail and wholesale and has been in this business for the last three years. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees. She is faced with high commodity prices, which chase away some of her long time customers.

Scholastica has been in MCDT for six years and is servicing her fifteenth loan, working all along with the same groupmates. She wants to use this loan to acquire a bigger place for her business and also aspires to own a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To acquire a bigger place for her retail business.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha has made a living selling soup and small side dishes in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for the last 15 years. She belongs to the Hatuchoki loan group, and currently earns an average profit of $155 a month by workling 16 hours a day. She is applying her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to sell. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business. 

Asha is 39 years old, married and has three children ages 4, 14 and 18. She also cares for two other dependants.

loans.use: To buy more items and expand her business.

loans.name: Colquiri Group

texts.es: El grupo " Colquiri " esta representado por el señor Henry Ronaldo y conformado por 12 miembros dedicados principalmente al comercio D. productos como ropa, refrescos, abarrotes, cosméticos, material escolar y a actividades como el servicio técnico en informática pero en general al transporte publico D. pasajeros. La competencia es granD. en lo que se refiere al trasporte en especial con la apertura D. nuevas rutas y mayor cantidad D. vehículos, es por esta razón que se ven en la obligación D. trabajar en turnos nocturnos hasta altas horas D. la noche y parte D. la madrugada para llevar la renta a la familia. El destino del financiamiento es para la reparación D. sus vehículos y herramientas D. trabajo y al mejoramiento D. las mismas. Los miembros del grupo han demostrado ser personas responsables y cumplidas ya que se dedican a su trabajo para poder brindar a sus familias una mejor calida D. vida con su trabajo y esfuerzo, en su mayoría los socios conocen el trabajo en grupos solidarios y conocen la responsabilidad D. sus obligaciones.
texts.en:
The group "Colquiri" is represented by Henry Ronaldo and is by 12 members. Their businesses incluD. the sale of products like clothing, drinks, groceries, cosmetics, and school supplies and services like informational technology and public transportation of passengers. There is much competition, especially in public transportation with the amount of vehicles on the road and the creation of new routes. For this reason, they are responsible for working night shifts, from the middle of the night to dawn to bring rent to their families. The loan will be used for working tools, costs related to repairing vehicles, and costs related to improving their conditions in general. The members of the group are responsible and committed. They strive to bring the best quality of life to their families. The partners are familiar with operating under solidarity groups and they understand the responsibilities involved in these obligations.

Translated from Spanish by Annie Sheng, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital for operations

loans.name: Abla

texts.fr: En  2000, B. Abla a commencé le commerce de charbons de bois, elle vend à ses clients en gros et en détail, actuellement la demande de sa clientèle est élevée, raison pour laquelle elle demande à WAGES un crédit qui lui permettrait d’acheter 10 sacs de charbons de bois. Elle est mariée à un menuisier et mère de 02 enfants. Dès fois le revenu de son mari ne couvre pas la totalité des charges de la famille, c’est donc avec le revenu de son commerce qu’elle contribue aux dépenses du foyer.
texts.en:
In 2000, Abla B. began to sell charcoal. She sells to her customers, both wholesale and retail. Presently, the demand of her clientele is high, and for that reason she is asking WAGES for a loan that will allow her to buy 10 sacks of charcoal. She is married to a carpenter and is the mother of 2 children. Sometimes her husband's income is not sufficient to cover all the expenses of the family, and it is her business income that makes up the difference.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of charcoal for re-sale

loans.name: Minda

texts.en:
Minda A. is a rice grower. She tills two hectares of land which she inherited from her parents. She is 46 years old and has five children. "Farming is interesting work", she said. " It is where we get the food that we give to our children", she added. Aside from growing rice, Minda is hoping to buy piglets to start her piggery. She thinks that their income in the farm is not enough to support them, especially in paying school fees and tuition.

She is requesting a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and other chemicals for the farm. The loan will definitely give her whole family a good harvest. 

CEVI is a Christian, non-profit organization and a partner of WorldVision Philippines. It is organized to help respond to the needs of our small entrepreneurs to grow their business. CEVI provides their clients with credit, training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and farm chemicals.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mrs. Mao N., a 36-year-old mother of three children attending the local school, lives in Rolus village in Takeo Province, where she breeds ducks. Since her poultry business is doing well, she is requesting a loan to expand it by purchasing more ducks to breed, hoping to thereby increase income and improve her family’s living conditions. Her husband, Mr. Tom Sovan, is a farmer who owns a plot of land upon which he cultivates rice. Mao and her husband are presented in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase more ducks to breed.

loans.name: Jemelita

texts.en:
"I have only a one hectare (2.5 acre) farm. This has helped me in providing for the needs of my children. We started by sowing corn. I was a tenant back then until we were able to buy our own farm. I am planning to buy a carabao (a domesticated subspecies of the water buffalo) in the future to be able to sustain our livelihood," says Mrs. Jemelita O., 32-year old mother of two children.

She would like a loan of Php 7,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizer and hybrid corn seed. The loan will truly help her get a better income for her family. She is now looking for some other possible income areas to contribute better to the family income.

Through CEVI, Mrs. O. is able to sustain her corn farm. She receives not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and hybrid corn seed

loans.name: Magdalina

texts.en: Magdalina M. is from the town of Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 64 years old, married, and has four adult children. Magdalina owns and operates a business buying and selling green bananas in the local market. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2000, Magdalina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Magdalina is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional green bananas for her business. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the needs of relatives and other family members. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional green bananas for her business

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Josefa

texts.en: Josefa S. is 53 years old, married with seven children.  They reside in Mialen,Clarin, Misamis Occidental.  Her loan is intended to buy vitamins and feed for her piglets.  She has been a member of Paglaum MPC since May 2009.  With the help of PMPC-Micofinance her business has grown and she has a better income now than before.  She hopes to have a comfortable life someday and the ability to send her children to school so they have a bright future.

loans.use: Purchase vitamins and feeds for piglets.

loans.name: Joseph Ngang'a

texts.en:
Joseph K. is a 43-year-old dairy farmer and photographer. He is married with three children and has been in the farming business for 22 years.

Joseph makes a monthly profit of about 20,000 Kenyan shillings (about $250 U.S.). He keeps his cows at his house at Mwimutu and sells milk at the local kiosk.  His photography business is based in Nairobi city where he serves a wide range of customers.

He learned about KADET from his neighbor. He plans to use this loan to upgrade his cows to the highest grade in order to better serve his customers. He also intends to open a good photography shop in Nairobi city equipped with modern technology.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy more dairy feed and digital camera equipment.

loans.name: Marlene

texts.en:
Señora Marlene appears in this photo in her sewing workshop together with her 16-year-old granddaughter. Marlene's sewing workshop is located within her home. She is 57 years old and has five adult children. Her husband is a carpenter who works independently.

Marlene has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos through her communal bank, "Nuevas Amigas" (New Friends), since the communal bank's founding nine years ago. Marlene invested in the sale of candies with her very first loan of 300 soles (about $100). At that time she was also studying sewing, and has devoted herself to sewing as a full time business venture for the past seven years. Marlene plans to use this loan of 1500 soles to invest in materials for her business (including fabrics, thread, etc.). Marlene's goal is to eventually have her own boutI., complete with show windows and mannequins, where she can display her clothing.

Marlene is pleased to be working with Manuela Ramos and is grateful for the organization's financial support. Combining her own efforts with the help of loans from Manuela Ramos, she was able to purchase her sewing machine. Marlene continues to develop as a microentrepreneur.

loans.use: Materials for sewing (fabrics, thread, etc.)

loans.name: Adidas Group

texts.en:
David L., 31, is a married father of two children ages 8 and 3. He operates a barber shop which he started in 2008.  He works from 8am to 10pm daily and is able to able to earn a monthly profit of about $304 US.

This will be David’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to improve the barber shop and has paid his loans back successfully. He now hopes for a new loan to further improve his business.

David will share this loan with subgroup A of the Adidas group. The subgroup has 7 members, who run shops, salons, and tailor and sell clothes. These members hold each other accountable to pay back their loans. In the picture, David is second from left in a blue t-shirt.

loans.use: To improve his barber shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Achat d'engrais et  d'intrants agricoles

loans.name: Jerry

texts.en:
Jerry S. is a rice farmer from Trento, Agusan Del Sur. He is 43 years old, married, and has five children. Currently, he tills a 2-hectare (~5-acre) rice field. 

This is Jerry's fourth loan from CEV. He believes that the biblical reflection during CEC cluster meetings really helped him and his fellow members.

Jerry is now requesting a loan of Php 10,000 to finance his farm. The loan will also be used to pay for farm laborers.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en:
Aidah is 48 and married with six children between the ages of 14 and 22. All her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members. Aidah resides in and owns a four-room house, where she is staying with five people. There is electricity and piped water at home. The family gets two meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. 

Aidah sells second-hand clothes on Lubaga road, one of roads leading to Kampala city. She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping at Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She doesn’t pay rent for her business as she works from her home. She sells to all categories of people on both a retail and wholesale basis. 

Aidah has been in this business for six years and also with MCDT for six years. She is now servicing her 15th loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of clothes. Aidah aspires to see her business grow bigger and to start going directly to Dubai for second-hand clothes.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Khanlar

texts.en: Khanlar has been in the house repair business for 5 years. He was born in 1966. Khanlar lives in Baku city, is married and has 2 children. He is now requesting a loan of 2000 AZN to buy necessary tools and supplies to improve his house repair business.

loans.use: to buy necessary tools and supplies to improve his house repair business

loans.name: Daylethan

texts.en: N. is 23 years old and lives with his parents and siblings in a house in the Bayan-Ulgii province of western Mongolia. Using his own truck, N. operates a coal trading business in his town. He makes approximately six trips per month to the capital of the province to buy coal and bring it back to his town for resale with each round trip totaling 300 kilometers. He began his business in 2007, and since then, he has made enough money to buy his own house. He says, “I am planning on getting married next year and because of that, I would like to expand my business in order to save up money so that I can start a family.” N. is requesting a 600,000 tugrug (~$420 U.S.) loan in order to purchase a large amount of coal for his business. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team. To see if there are other Mongolian borrowers in need of funding, please click here

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of coal for resale.

loans.name: Marie-Claire

texts.fr: G. Marie-Claire est née vers 1970 et est mariée à AHOUANSOU Cyprien, un revendeur. Le couple a sept enfants, dont quatre sont à leur charge. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Marie-Claire vit avec son mari et ses enfants depuis 13 ans à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Marie-Claire supporte avec son mari les charges de la famille. Marie-Claire n'a pas été à l'école. Cela fait près de 7 ans que Marie-Claire vend des bois de chauffage à Ekpè, pour subvenir à ses besoins. C'est à Pahou dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin, que Marie-Claire s'approvisionne. Marie-Claire a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. En vue de renforcer son activité et de satisfaire plus sa clientèle, Marie-Claire sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
G. Marie-Claire was born in 1970 and is married to Ahouansou Cyprien, a re-seller. The couple has 7 children, 4 of whom are still in their care. All of the children attend school. For the past 13 years, Marie-Claire has lived with her husband and their children in Sèmè-Podji, in Benin. With her husband, Marie-Claire pays for the needs of her family. Marie-Claire did not attend school. For 7 years, Marie-Claire has sold firewood in Ekpè, in order to provide for her family's needs. Marie-Claire supplies herself in Pahou, in the district of Atlantique in Bénin. Marie-Claire has benefitted from one loan from ALIDé, which she fully repaid. In order to strengthen her business and satisfy more of her clientele, Marie-Claire is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase firewood in bulk

loans.name: Omolara

texts.en: Omolara sells hair extensions and hair cream at retail prices in her shop. She is not a hair stylist but she sells hair materials to make a living. She is happy because the high season is here and she hopes to make more sales during this season. She is 33 years old; married with 4 children. Her children are doing well in school. Omolara is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She hopes for the loan of NGN 120,000 to purchase more hair extensions and hair cream to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.es: Esperanza de 49 años vive en su casa propia, al lado de sus dos hijos que le ayudan mucho en sus labores diarias.Desde hace mas de 20 años se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza de una reconocida marca a nivel mundial , además se encarga de la distribución de estos productos al resto de  trabajadoras de la empresa que viven por su zona , es la  líder,  y  quiere en un futuro convertirse en capitana con lo cual recibirá un buen sueldo por las buenas ventas, pero por el momento se encuentra tranquila con su trabajo ya que la hace sentir  independiente y le permite pasar mucho tiempo con sus hijos,además ellos la quieren y respetan. Aparte de su negocio de venta de cosméticos, tiene un locutorio de alquiler de teléfonos, el cual atiende con  la ayuda de su hija.Ya es el catorceavo préstamo que tiene con MFP y promete ser responsable en cada uno de los pagos.Con el dinero del crédito comprará mayor cantidad de productos de belleza para tenerlo en stock en estas épocas navideñas y también para invertirlo en algunos muebles que le hacen falta en su negocio del locutorio.
texts.en:
Esperanza is 49. She lives in her own house with her two children; they help her a lot with her daily work. For over 20 years she has been selling a brand of beauty products that is known worldwide. Also, she sees to the distribution of these products to the rest of the company workers who live in her area. She is the leader. In the future she would like to become the captain, which would give her a good salary for good sales. At the moment she is at peace with her work because it makes her feel independent. It also allows her to spend a lot of time with her children who love and respect her. Besides her business of selling cosmetics, she has a calling center and rents phones. She takes care of it with her daughter’s help. This is her fourteenth loan with MFP. She promises to be responsible in every one of her payments. She will use the money from the loan to buy a greater quantity of beauty products to have in stock for this Christmas season. She will also buy some furniture that she needs for her calling center business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a larger quantity of merchandise for her business

loans.name: Mrs. On Duch Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. On D. leads a loan group made up of 14 people who hope to use their funds in maN. different ways. All of the members live in Preaek Khmaer village in Kandal province. Mrs. On D. is a farmer who owns a plot of land. Her husband, Mr. Thy Chum, is a fisherman who makes a small income. Although they tried to save some money to plant a crop this year, they were unable to do so. That is why Mrs. On D. has decided to apply for a loan to buy seeds, fertilizer, pesticides and fuel. This couple has four children, all of whom attend the local public school.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer, pesticide and fuel.

loans.name: Kristine Ivy

texts.en:
Kristine Ivy T. is from the town of San Fabian Echague. She is 27 years old. Kristine Ivy is single.  Kristine Ivy owns & operates a restaurant.  The main source of income for the business comes from serving specialty foods & delicacies to customers in the local community. Kristine Ivy has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month (about $429 US).

In 2008, Kristine Ivy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Kristine Ivy from ASKI.  She successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from ASKI, which she used to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. Kristine Ivy is requesting another loan of 50,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Food & drinks for a restaurant

loans.name: God Dae Group

texts.en: Mariama K. who is on the right of the photo, is the leader of this group of local entrepreneurs who named their group God Dae. They have come to SMT/Kiva lenders for the first time to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person for the purpose of expanding their businesses. Thirty-two-year-old Mariama sells head-ties, bowls, dishes and women’s clothes. She has been in this business for 2 years now. Mariama was born in Bo City, in southern Sierra Leone. She is married to a soldier and they have 2 children, one in primary school and the other in secondary school. Mariama wants this loan in order to expand her business by buying the above-mentioned items in wholesale.

loans.use: To buy head-ties, bowls, dishes and women’s clothes to sell.

loans.name: Sarantuya

texts.en:
Sarantuya D. is a 43 year old married mother of one son. Her son, Luvsandondog, attends the local elementary school. Since 2002, Sarantuya has run a clothing stall at the local market with her husband Lhagvasuren. When she started her business, she rented a stall. After a few years of hard work, she bought the stall she was renting.

They are planning to buy a condominium in next few months with the profits from their business. Sarantuya goes to Ereen, a city on the border with China, once a month to purchase a variety of apparel for men and women. She requests a loan to purchase spring clothing to increase her sales.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah is fashion designer who makes lovely Nigerian designs for her customers as well as selling sewing materials. She loves this business because it allows her to help support her family. Her challenge is funding and she hopes to overcome this challenge. She is 35 and married with one child. She is requesting a loan of N80,000 to buy more sewing materials to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sewing materials to sell
